page.title: 14THE WRECK OF THE NORDEN
page.content: TOWARDS THE SOUTHERN END OF THE BEACH, THE BONES OF WRECKED BOAT, THE NORTHERN ARE EXPOSED AT LOW TIDE AND PROVIDE AN INTEREST FOR YOUNG AND OLD. IN 1897, A WESTERLY GALE DROVE THE NORWEGIAN BARGE ONTO THE BEACH AT BERROW.THE CREW WERE TAKEN OFF BY THE BURNHAM-ON-SEA LIFEBOAT AND LATER, AS THE TIDE DROPPED, THE CAPTAIN WAS ABLE TO JUMP INTO THE SURF AND WADE ASHORE. DESPITE EFFORTS MADE IT WAS IMPOSSIBLE TO REFLOAT THE BARGE.THE FIGUREHEAD ADORNS A LOCAL COTTAGE AND SOME OF THE TIMBERS WERE 'RESCUED' AND USED BY LOCAL FARMERS. TODAY, THE KEEL AND RIBS CAN BE EXPLORED AND THE COPPER NAILS AND GRANITE BALLAST FORM ON INTEREST TO YOUNG EXPLORERS.
